definition: "An application programming interface (API) is a connection between computers or between computer programs. It is a type of software interface
column4: offering a service to other pieces of software.[1] A document or standard that describes how to build or use such a connection or interface is called an API specification. A computer system that meets this standard is said to implement or expose an API. The term API may refer either to the specification or to the implementation."

definition: "A web API is an application programming interface for either a web server or a web browser. It is a web development concept
column4: usually limited to a web application's client-side (including any web frameworks being used)
column5: and thus usually does not include web server or browser implementation details such as SAPIs or APIs unless publicly accessible by a remote web application."

definition: "Webservice
column4: a service offered by an electronic device to another electronic device
column5: communicating with each other via the Internet"

definition: "A metadata repository is the database where metadata is stored. The registry also adds relationships with related metadata types. A metadata engine collects
column4: stores and analyzes information about data and metadata (data about data) in use within a domain"

definition: "A database catalog consists of metadata in which definitions of database objects such as base tables
"A web portal is a specially designed website that brings information from diverse sources
"A data library data archive or data repository is a collection of numeric and/or geospatial data sets for secondary use in research"
"A folder of files accessible via the web"

WebDAV (Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning) is a set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), which allows user agents to collaboratively author contents directly in an HTTP web server by providing facilities for concurrency control and namespace operations, thus allowing Web to be viewed as a writeable, collaborative medium and not just a read-only medium. WebDAV is defined in RFC 4918 by a working group of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF).
A thesaurus or synonym dictionary is a reference work for finding synonyms and sometimes antonyms of words
"Controlled vocabularies provide a way to organize knowledge for subsequent retrieval. They are used in subject indexing schemes

column7: authorised terms that have been preselected by the designers of the schemes
column8: in contrast to natural language vocabularies

definition: "inputs outputs constraints sequencing information involved in business or engineering processes."

A data model is an abstract model that organizes elements of data and standardizes how they relate to one another and to the properties of real-world entities. For instance a data model may specify that the data element representing a car be composed of a number of other elements which in turn represent the color and size of the car and define its owner.

In knowledge representation and reasoning, knowledge graph is a knowledge base that uses a graph-structured data model or topology to integrate data. Knowledge graphs are often used to store interlinked descriptions of entities – objects, events, situations or abstract concepts – while also encoding the semantics underlying the used terminology.[1]
"Extract Transform & Load mechanism to transfer data from 1 model to another"
"Codelists provide an enumerated list of allowable values. Codelists can be used by Dimensions
column5: and Metadata Attributes to define the allowable content for both data and metadata reporting. Each Codelist contains zero to many Codes
column6: each Code much belong to a Codelist."

definition: FAIR data are data which meet principles of findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability.[1][2] The acronym and principles were defined in a March 2016 paper in the journal Scientific Data by a consortium of scientists and organizations.

The INSPIRE Directive aims to create a European Union spatial data infrastructure for the purposes of EU environmental policies and policies or activities which may have an impact on the environment. This European Spatial Data Infrastructure will enable the sharing of environmental spatial information among public sector organisations, facilitate public access to spatial information across Europe and assist in policy-making across boundaries.

The Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) is an international consortium of more than 500 businesses, government agencies, research organizations, and universities driven to make geospatial (location) information and services FAIR - Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable.

The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) is an international community where Member organizations, a full-time staff, and the public work together to develop Web standards. Led by Web inventor and Director Tim Berners-Lee and CEO Jeffrey Jaffe, W3C's mission is to lead the Web to its full potential. Contact W3C for more information.
Linked Open Data (LOD) is Linked Data which is released under an open license, which does not impede its reuse for free.

Climate change and environmental degradation are an existential threat to Europe and the world. To overcome these challenges, the European Green Deal will transform the EU into a modern, resource-efficient and competitive economy
"The Data Act is a key measure for making more data available for use in line with EU rules and values."

any system that perceives its environment and takes actions that maximize its chance of achieving its goals
the process of extracting and discovering patterns in large data sets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning

"Deep learning (also known as deep structured learning) is part of a broader family of machine learning methods based on artificial neural networks with representation learning. Learning can be supervised
column4: semi-supervised or unsupervised. The adjective "deep" in deep learning refers to the use of multiple layers in the network."
